A court ruling this week has thrown a monkey wrench into one of the ways the government goes after corporate criminals.
The case involves 16 former employees of an accounting firm called KPMG.
Their trial on charges of massive tax fraud isn't scheduled to begin till September.
But the implications of this week's ruling by U.S.
District Judge Louis Kaplan stretch beyond the particulars of this case.
Jennifer Arlen teaches business crime at NYU Law School and joins us now.
Welcome.
Nice to be here.
Can you sort of back us up and take us into this case, and explain to us what really is at issue in this ruling?

This case deals with the question of whether there are any limits on what the government can require a corporation to do, in return for the government agreeing not to exercise its lawful right to prosecute the corporation for its employee's wrongdoing.
And Judge Kaplan concluded that the government may require firms to do certain things in return for not being prosecuted, like cooperate.
But the government may not pressure corporations into withholding attorneys fees from its employees in return for the government not prosecuting the corporation.
Now, I understand this is part of a broader policy at the Justice Department, as far as the way that the government goes after corporate crime.
This is part of a policy that's expressed in something called the Thompson Memo.

And the Thompson Memo is the most recent expression of a change in the government's policy that started in the early 1990s, where the government recognized that a very important way that the government could prevent business crime is to detect it and actually prosecute the employees who do it.
And it cannot do that effectively unless the corporations cooperate and give it the information it requires.
